title: Kenya: Government Paying Sh2 Billion to Underage Staff
text:
Nigeria: Workers Earned N730 Per Hour in Q2 - NBS By James Mbaka 
The government loses Sh2 billion annually in a salary mega scam involving ghost workers who are dead or retired and school-going children of senior civil servants, a report has revealed. 
Documented ghost workers number at least 4,674 and another 10,280 employee records are suspicious, it said. 
Of these, about 500 ghost workers are under age 18, according to the report. 
Another 1,628 'employees' draw salaries and allowances, despite having reached mandatory retirement age of 60 and not having signed extension contracts. 
Yet another 2,546 people, including those who have retired or died, continue to draw salaries. 
The report was prepared by the Inter-Governmental Steering Committee for the Capacity Assessment and Rationalization of the Public Service programme. 
Biometric registration was launched in July last year to weed out ghost workers. 
"There should be investigation and action taken for the illegal recruitment of the employees in the periods 
indicated and sanctions on the officers involved," the report says. 
Chairperson of the Public Service Commission 
Prof Margaret Kobia yesterday said forensic investigations are underway to identify the cheats. 
"Some 50 culprits have been identified and we have a team working on this. If we confirm these are the people behind the fraud and the so-called ghost workers, we shall institute disciplinary and legal action immediately," Kobia said. 
Further, the report says 10,280 employee records require follow-up and investigation to unearth individuals using duplicate documentation to infiltrate government salary accounts. 
The payroll fraudsters, for instance, used one payroll number (identity withheld by the Star) to pay a salary six times for years. 
Another 112 Identity Cards, which were virtually identical, were used to milk taxpayers of money in the well- coordinated 
scheme involving senior government officials with access to the payroll. 
Suspicious characters also used 367 replicated PIN numbers to access money paid to nonexistent workers. 
An earlier assessment had revealed that the government was losing Sh70 million in eight state departments through salaries to nonexistent workers. 
The biometric audit of the civil service staff launched in July last year indicated 485duplicate records were used to access government salaries after the state payroll was violated by internal fraudsters. 
The Secretary General of the Union of Kenya Civil Servants Tom Odege challenged the government to thoroughly clean up its payroll and rid it of waste. 
"If ghosts can earn Sh1.8 billion from government annually and the government is not aware, then no Kenyan is safe. They must clean up the payroll and use the money to enhance working environment for our members,"Odege said. 
The report said that out of the 8,979 employees in the Integrated Payroll and Personnel Database who were not biometrically registered, 4,541 are unaccounted for. 
"For those unaccounted for, there is need for further investigation to determine whether loss of funds has already occurred in terms of erroneous/fraudulent payments," the report says. Of the 199,921 public servants, only 163,543 were found to be duly registered in the integrated payroll system, while 36,378 newly employed staff are yet to be integrated into the system. 
Both the national government and the county governments employ ghost workers. The committee recommends drastic action, including linking the payroll system, and hence data, with the National Registry to create one database of employee records and therefore minimise incidences of fraudulent activity/ghost workers," the report says. It calls for ending government payments through vouchers that can be manipulated. 
"Employment of casuals presents the inherent risk of violating employment laws if not controlled and monitored," the committee noted Kenya
